{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Imagine that you have a magic toaster that cann toast bread in all different ways ... now imagine if you have a million of these magic toasters all stuck together at the same time changing independently, but all making and eating the different toasts simultaneously. This is, sort of, what quantum computers are, but with bits instead of toast.     Regular, or classical, computers are built with one-bit things that are either turned off or on. We call the turned off state 0 and the turned on state 1. Certain combinations of 0's and 1's can mean different things. For example 1011 might be the instruction to send a bit of information to your printer, or it could represent a letter in the alphabet, or it could be a number like 15. Now, 1011 is made of four bits, which means that each of the bits has to be either off or on.     Quantum computers are made of quantum bits, or qubits. A qubit can be both 0 and 1 at the same time. This is called superposition. If it were just a matter of being 0 and 1 at the same time, that wouldn't be very useful, but qubits are able to interact with each other through a process called entanglement. Entanglement means that qubits are linked together so that when one changes, another changes in response.     Because of this, a quantum computer with two qubits could be 1 and 0, or 0 and 1, or both 1 and 0. whereas a classical computer can only be 1 and 0 or 0 and 1. A quantum computer with three qubits could have any combination of 1 and 0 for the three bits (that's eight combinations), but if they weren't entangled, you would have to prepare for each situation separately. With classical computer you would have to prepare for each possibility. The number of combinations you have to prepare for grows exponentially, which means that the growth rate gets faster as the numbers get bigger. So, for qubits, if you added 4 more bits (for a total of 7) you would have to prepare for 2.5 times as many combinations as before. Add in 10 more (17 total) and you would have to prepare for more than 10,000 times as many combinations. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Quantum computing is the use of quantum phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. COMPUTING VECTOR: The basic unit of quantum computation is a quantum bit or \"qubit\", which defines a two-dimensional quantum system. Quantum gates manipulate an input of qubits into a different output of qubits, in a reversible fashion. The quantum circuit is then measured to obtain a result. The power of quantum computing comes from the possibility of being in many different states at one time (superposition). If we have one quantum bit, it can be in a superposition of two different states (for instance |0> and |1>). If we have two bits, they can be in a superposition of four different states (|00>, |01>, |10>, |11>), and three bits eight states and so on.    The gates most commonly used in quantum computing come from the DiVincenzo/Ryan (DVR) gate library. A recent development is a class of gates called \"XYX\" which has properties that may decrease the error rate. There is also a quantum compiler which translates calculations into quantum computer steps.     ALGORITHMS OVER CLASSICAL ONES: Shor's quantum factoring algorithm is a quantum algorithm that factors integers in polynomial time, which would break the widely-used RSA public key cryptography. Another famous example is Grover's algorithm. Grover's algorithm can speed up computations for unstructured search problems by doing O(\\sqrt{N}) operations instead of O(N) operations.     Noisy quantum computers are unlikely to be able to simulate ideal quantum gates to arbitrarily small error. If noisy quantum computers can efficiently simulate ideal quantum circuits to within fixed error, it would mean quantum computers can tolerate errors without error correction, which most researchers consider unlikely.     In quantum complexity theory, BQP is the class of problems solvable by a quantum computer in polynomial time, with error probability of at most 1/3 for all instances (i.e., with a probability of at least 2/3 of obtaining the right answer).    HISTORY: The origins of quantum computing includes a 1980 speech by Paul Benioff describing a quantum mechanical Turing machine. In 1981, Richard Feynman gave a lecture about simulating physics on a computer. He said that there would be major advantages to using quantum systems for computation instead of traditional computing, but did not show how to do a quantum computation. David Deutsch, in 1985, gave a description of a quantum Turing machine. In 1989, Deutsch, Toffoli, and Lloyd showed that a universal quantum computer can approximate the dynamics of any other quantum system.     TECHNOLOGY: The first demonstration of Grover's algorithm was shown in 1998 in NMR. The first demonstration of Shor's algorithm was also in NMR. The most popular technology used to date for demonstrating quantum algorithms is NMR, for which small computers have been built with up to about 7 qubits. Potential advantages of NMR include no need for cooling and flexible control. Transmon qubits are the qubit of the state-of-the-art superconducting quantum processors. Since 2011 Google has employed D-Wave's processors for various proof-of-concept quantum applications. In 2019 JB Straubel, co-founder and former CTO of Tesla, bought a stake in D-Wave. Agarwal says the investment signaled a shift in how quantum computing is perceived, especially for companies interested in exploring its potential applications. Here are some definitions of the different types of science fiction.       -  Action - stories with lots of movement and exciting events.    -  Adventure - stories with exciting events.    -  Aliens - stories involving beings from other worlds.    -  Alternate histories - stories that imagine what might have happened if historical events had happened differently.    -  Apocalyptic fiction - stories about the end of civilization.    -  Arthurian - stories that center around King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table.    -  Astrobiology - stories about the origin, evolution, and future of life on earth and in outer space.    -  Cli-fi - stories about climate and environmental change.    -  Dystopian - stories that exaggerate social problems to create a nightmare world.    -  Hard science fiction - stories that are careful to follow all the scientific rules.    -  Heroic children - stories of fantastic adventures with magical powers.    -  Humour - stories to make you laugh.    -  Martian - stories involving the planet Mars.    -  Military - stories centered on military and warfare.    -  Parallel universes - stories of worlds existing beside our own.    -  Paranormal - stories that involve phenomena beyond the scope of normal scientific understanding.    -  Planetary romance - stories about adventures on alien planets.    -  Robots - stories involving robots.    -  Science fantasies - stories that blend science fiction, fantasy, and mythology.    -  Social - stories that concentrate on social and political change.    -  Space - stories where the main action takes place in outer space.    -  Space opera - stories with romantic, often melodramatic adventure set mainly or entirely in outer space.    -  Spy - stories about spies and espionage.    -  Steampunk - stories involving 19th century steam-powered machinery.    -  Time travel - stories about travel forward and backward through time.    -  Utopian - stories about ideal or perfect societies. The couple eventually rents a room above a storefront as their headquarters. Part 3: Smith and Julia are caught by the Thought Police, taken to the Ministry of Love, and subjected to a laundry list of physical and emotional tortures. After Smith makes a full confession, the cruelty subsides, and he is taken to the Chestnut Tree Café, where dissidents gather to drink gin and listen to music played on a tinny piano. Those in power seem to be immortal, as their portraits never change. They are Alll-powerful, and their will is law. Back in the past, before the Party was in control, citizens of London in particular were paranoid and unable to trust anyone. prompt: How can I improve my sleep quality Any tips?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Most people can benefit from improving their sleep hygiene. Sleep hygiene is the set of behaviors that help a person prepare for sleep and stay asleep until it's time to get up. It involves getting into a daily sleep routine, improving your sleep environment, setting a bedtime and wake-up time, and changing daytime habits that negatively affect sleep such as drinking caffeine or exercising too late in the day. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Creating a budget is essential for taking control of your fianances. Follow these steps to create a budget that works for you. 1. Determine how much money you receive each month In order to accurately prepare a budget, you first need to know exactly how much money you have each month. Use your net income, that is the money you actually have in hand and can spend, instead of your gross income, which is your income minus taxes. Take your net income from your job and add any extra income you receive such as deposits from the sale of goods or services, interest and dividends from investments, and income from gifts, alimony, lottery prizes and other sources. 2. Write down everything you spend money on for at least a week Keeping a spending diary will tell you where your money goes. If the purchases are many and small, you may not even remember them. If the purchases are large, you may not be able to guess the exact amount. To make a spending diary, get some paper and pen and for the next week write down everyday all your expenses. Write down the purchase and its cost. 3. Add your expenses together and see how much you spend each month Add the total expenses and compare it to your monthly income. If you spend more than you bring in, that is a problem. But it also means that a budget could help you. 4. Separate your needs from your wants You need food, shelter and clothing. But every time you buy a coffee, go out to eat for lunch or order in pizza you are buying a want. Instead of a coffee maker for your home, you buy the \"Barista Collection\". Make it a goal to cut down on the maximum number of wants you can afford and still be happy. 5. Make a budget page for each type of expense It is easiest to use a computer program, but you can also use paper. A budget has three parts: income (money you make or receive), fixed expenses and variable expenses. Your income is how much money you have. Fixed expenses cannot be changed: your rent or house payments, car payments and insurance. The amount of your variable expenses such as utilities, food, clothing and entertainment varies from month to month. 6. Decide how much you want to budget for each budget type Sum up the amounts you budget for each of your expense types. This should not be more than your monthly income. (If it is, cut back on some categories or find ways to increase your income.) To make sure you stick to your budget, you can withdraw money as cash and place them in envelopes for each category. When the money is gone it means you have no more money for that category. 7. Compare your expenses to your budget Every once and a while, check to see whether you are spending what you budgeted for. You might be able to save money or need to increase the amount for some categories.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you make a plan for your money, you should have enough to pay for your needs and some of your wants. Here are the basics to creating a budget: Take stock of the money you receive         Your income is the money you get from work, investments, pensions, gifts, and help from the government.    Take stock of the money you spend    Your expenses are the things you pay for. Some expenses are the same each month, such as a phone bill. Other expenses are different each month, such as buying an appliance.    Figure out your savings    Think about what you want to save for, such as a new appliance or a vacation. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Creating a budget is an important first step to managing your money. A budget is a list of your expenses and how much money you have to pay those expenses. To create a budget:       - Prioritize spending. You need to make a list of your monthly expenses starting with your essentials. For most people, the essentials include a place to live, utilities, food, childcare, and transportation. If you have debt, you may want to list that as an essential until your debt is paid off.    - List your non-essentials. These include extras such as entertainment, clothing (beyond everyday clothing needs), and gifts.      - Figure out how much money you have to spend. Use your paycheck stubs or bank statements to figure out your average monthly income.    - Compare your expenses to actual spending. Keeping track of everything you spend for a week or two will give you a good idea of what your expenses really are. You may need to adjust your budget after you see where your money is going.    - Set spending goals. Your last goals should be for non-essentials. Setting a goal of zero for non-essentials is not realistic for most people so make sure you have a goal for each non-essential category.    - Check your progress. Each player begins the game with 16 pieces: one king, one queen, two rooks, two knights, two bishops, and eight pawns. Each of the six piece types moves differently, with the most powerful being the queen and the least powerful the pawn. The players take turns moving one piece at a time, with White moving first. There are also two special moves in chess: castling and en passant. Castling is where a rook and the king are moved during the same turn. En passant is a special pawn capture that can only occur when one player moves their pawn two squares forward from its starting position, and an enemy pawn could have captured it \"en passant\" if it had moved only one square forward. In addition, when a pawn reaches the other side of the board, it is promoted and must be exchanged for a queen, rook, bishop or knight of the same color. The object of the game is to checkmate the opponent's king. This happens when the king is under immediate attack and there is no way for it to escape. If a player's king is threatened with capture, the king is said to be in check. However, if you are going on a long trip, you need to plan ahead. Here are some tips to help you prepare for your trip:       - Plan your route. Include options for fueling up, getting something to eat, and rest stops.     - Make a packing list. Include all the essentials for you, your passengers and your car, such as medications, snacks, electronics and chargers, emergency supplies and entertainment.    - Check the weather forecast and be flexible. For safety, you may need to change your plans.    - Get your car ready. Check the oil, tire pressure and other routine maintenance items.    - Consider adjusting your schedule. Traveling in the middle of the day can be stressful; at night, it can be tiring. Most people prefer to leave and arrive in the morning. Be alert for congestion around major holidays.     - Drive with care.    - Choose lodging that fits your needs.    - Take breaks. When possible, don't try to cover too many miles in a day. Taking breaks will help keep you refreshed and alert on the road.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Whether you want to stop at a small town along the way or visit a national park, planning a trip in the country can take some work. Here are some things to consider:       Make a list of the places you want to go and the things you want to see. It is usually a good idea to have several alternatives in mind. It is also a good idea to plan activities and trips for when the weather is likely to be good. Check the weather before you leave to adjust your schedule, if necessary.    Make an itinerary. An itinerary is simply a list of the places you will stay and the things you plan to do on a trip.    Make any necessary reservations. If you want to be sure you have a place to stay, make reservations well in advance.    Prepare your travel supplies. Consider such things as clothing, money, food and drink, maps and guide books, pillows and blankets and your choice of entertainment.    Make a list of things you must have before you leave - such as medicine, children's belongings and stuff for house and lawn care.    Pack your bags. Pack early so you won't be rushed and forget anything.    Make sure your home is in order before you leave. Consider temporarily stopping mail delivery, removing items of value from sight, locking doors and windows, giving a key to a trusted friend or neighbor, asking that person to monitor your house and making sure the yard is tended.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Road trips offer the freedom to travel at your own pace and the opportunity to see what you want, when you want. But it helps to have a road trip strategy.     Decide where you want to go. Is it a list of a few cities you want to visit, or do you want to drive a particular route? If you have a bunch of places in mind, decide the order you want to see them. Remember it is not just the destinations, but often the drive itself that is the fun of a road trip.     Figure out how much driving you can do comfortably in a day. Plan extra time for rest stops, sightseeing, meals, and overnight stays if you don't want to drive straight through.     Consider the seasons and weather. Some roads have seasonal closings. In the winter, some may be snowbound, impassable, or dangerous.      Plan where to stay overnight. There may be towns or attractions along the way that you want to visit. Are there enough hotels, motels, and campgrounds? Some roads aren't near places to stay so you may need to plan driving detours.     Pack an emergency car kit. It should include a flashlight and batteries, jumper cables, toolkit, basic auto repair products, car and road maps, first aid kit and manual, bottled water and non-perishable food, tissues and wipes, paper and pens, candles and matches. Provided by U.S. Department of Transportation Office of Public Affairs.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Start mapping out your route with help from online road trip planners, and then read up on lodging and things to do along the way. Road trips require a little more planning than air travel. It is important to know where you will stay and what you will do while on the road. Most destinations have a trip-planning Web site; search for \"[destination name] tourism\" to find one. Many offer online maps and trip planners, travel guides and suggested itineraries, and information about events. Getting tips from travel books and Web sites geared toward travelers may help you see more along the way. Be sure to research your car needs. It is a good idea to bring a spare tire, repair kit and jumper cables. Consider whether you need to rent a car, and if so, book early for the best deal and availability. Make sure you have car insurance that covers rental cars and that you understand what your own insurance company covers while you are driving out of state.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Taking a road trip can be a great way to see the country, but there are important things to know. Here are some tips to help you avoid problems. Plan route before you go    - Check the weather.    - Check conditions on your route.    - Make an itinerary and make reservations.       Check your car     - See if your auto insurance policy is up to date.     - Get the car checked and serviced if needed.     - Get a copy of your vehicle registration, just in case.      When traveling in another country     - It's a good idea to read the U.S. Department of State's country specific information pages before you leave. They offer travel tips and alerts.    - If you think there is a chance that a disaster will strike while you are away it is a good idea to let someone at home know where you will be. Make sure they have emergency contact information for you.    - Make copies of your insurance policies to take with you.     - Make sure your health insurance will cover you while you are outside the country.     - If you want to make sure the U.S. government knows you are in another country, you can register in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How do I plan a road trip?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Road trips are awesome! They can be the adventure of a lifetime, the highlight of your summer, or the perfect getaway from work. While there is no \"one size fits all\" method to planning a road trip, there are some common parts to every road trip planning process. Figure out where you want to go, who you want to go with, your trip's duration, and how much it will cost (or your spending limit). Then decide on an itinerary and make reservations, if necessary. After that, you'll be ready to prep your home and pack the car. You can find more on this site about each of these steps.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

From choosing the route to building a playlist, the key to a successful road trip is in the planning. You are probably looking forward to seeing the world out the car window, but road trips can be fun and enjoyable, too. Road trips can have more ups and downs than plane trips. Spending long hours together in a car can cause tempers to fray. Occasional stops can cause delays. Road trips require more work from travelers than do plane trips. On the road, YOU are the one in control - not a driver or airline employee. With control comes responsibility. If you choose to go by car, plan for the long haul. All road trips can be fun with just a little planning.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Planning a road trip can be fun. Here are a few things to consider when planning your roadmap:       - Determine your destination -- where do you want to go?    - Decide on your travel budget -- how much can you spend?    - Gather travel information -- whether you are traveling domestically or internationally check out travel guides for tourism boards and bureaus to get more info.    - Book travel and hotels – if you don't want to rough it, you need to know where to stay along the way.    - Plan sightseeing -- check out travel websites for kid-friendly destinations, family history places, interesting sites and tours, and other attractions that are on your way.    - Plan activities -- do you want to spend the day snorkeling, hiking, museum touring, shopping, or simply relaxing?    - Make local dining reservations.     - Plan shopping -- know where the outlets are located, where the antique shops are, and where to get your souvenirs.    - Pack a suitcase or two -- don't forget medications and chargers for technical equipment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Are you thinking about jumping in the car and going on a road trip? Whether you've planned the trip or you're being spontaneous, there are a few tips to make sure your trip is safe and enjoyable. If you want to see several places in a region, try mapping a driving loop. prompt: How do I prepare for a job interview Any tips?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Here are some tips to help you prepare for your interview:        - Find out as much as you can about the position you are applying for. From the employer, find out the dates you will be available to work, how far you are able to travel or commute, and your salary requirements.    - Make a list of your skills and how they can help you do the job. Make sure to practice answering questions about your skills, abilities and work history. Think about telling the employer about a situation in which you were successful.    - Think about and practice answers to questions you will likely be asked like \"Why do you want to work here?\" \"What are your strengths and weaknesses?\" and \"Tell me about yourself.\"    - Decide what you will wear to the interview and make sure they are ready. Topics in the media have emphasized \"appropriate\" interview attire for both women and men. \"Appropriate\" attire will vary according to the type of job for which you are applying.     - Make sure you have all the information you need to get to the location, and you have the phone number, in case you need to reschedule.    - Gather your paperwork. Make sure you have your resume and any other documents, such as references, work samples, letters of recommendation and so on that were requested.    - Get a good night's sleep prior to the interview.     - Be sure to be on time, be polite, and make eye contact. Sit up straight and don't fidget. Relax and be yourself.    - Have a list of questions about the company and the position ready to ask when given the opportunity after the interviewer's questions.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You can prepare for a job interview by researching the agency, the job duties, and the people who will interview you. Practice potential questions and arrange for an interviewer to critique your interviewing style. Dress professionally and have a copy of your application and any supporting documentation with you. Be prepared to discuss your education, experience, and why you would like the job. Be positive and polite!     Find more information on preparing for an interview on About Federal Jobs   for usajobs.gov   and Sample Questions to Ask in an Interview   on career.govt.nz.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you have a job interview, you may feel anxious and wonder how to prepare. That is understandable. Preparing for an interview takes time, but being prepared will help ease your mind.    Here are some actions you can take to prepare for a job interview. They will help you build confidence and will help the interview go as well as it can.       -  Study the job announcement    -  Think about job interview questions and how you would answer them    -  Decide on the appropriate clothing for the interview    -  Visit the office where you will be interviewed so you know how long it will take you to get there on interview day.    -  Make a list of questions to ask the interviewer       Department of Labor","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Research the organization. Find out as much as you can about the organization before you go for the interview. Visit the organization's Web site to see what they do and how they describe themselves. You might also want to visit the news media's World Wide Web sites to find out if the organization has been in the news recently.    Practice. Find out what the most common interview questions are and practice your answers.     Contact your references and ask their permission to use them. Make sure your references will be positive. Contact some of your references and ask them if you can use them when you are looking for a job. Make sure they will be positive about you.    Check your suitability. In the interview you will be asked why you are a good candidate for the job. Think about your skills, interests, and values and how they match to the job.     Check your appearance. The first impression you make is your appearance. You want to look neat and clean. Make sure to wear the right clothes for the job.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Find out as much as you can about the company or organization before the interview. Get ready to talk about your capabilities. Explain what you did and how you did it instead of just what your job was. Make a list of the questions that you want to ask the interviewer. Practice answering common interview questions. Think of situations when you had to solve a problem or work with a difficult person. Think of examples when you set and reached goals. Most problems, goals and accomplishments have some direct link to a success factor or skill required to do the job. prompt: How do I prepare for a job interview Can you explain?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Before Your Interview???Preparation begins before the interview, and it starts with knowing as much as possible about the employer, the position for which you are applying, and the job market for your skills. It is crucial to gather this information because you will use it to convince the employer that you are the best qualified for the job. You should also prepare answers for the most common interview questions. Doing so will greatly increase your confidence and reduce any nervousness you may feel. Some sample questions include:       - Where do you see yourself in five years?    - What are your strengths and weaknesses?    - Why should we hire you?       Your appearance is another important area for interview preparation. While clothing and hairstyles are not an indicator of ability, employers want to see someone who is well-groomed and cares about his or her appearance. Reach for the job over the fashion statement. That means neat, clean, and conservative.    During Your Interview???Before you even say a word in the interview, you will have the job or not. Your appearance and confidence make up most of the first impression. If you are shy, prepare ways to break the ice before the question and answer session starts. You should know what to say and how to act in the following situations:       - Handshake: every interview begins and ends with a handshake. Make your shake firm and confident.    - Greeting: Greet the interviewer with a smile. If you know the person's name, use it.    - Leaving the room: always face the door when leaving. If the person who interviewed you does not move you should.    - Ending the interview: shake hands and tell the interviewer that you would like to work there.    - Questions: Answer honestly, without rambling. Also be prepared to ask questions. Most interviews end with the interviewer asking if you have questions. This not only shows that you are seriously thinking about the job but also gives you one last chance to make a good impression.       After Your Interview???After the interview, it is a good idea to send a short thank you note. Writing the note also helps you reflect on what you learned from the interview. You should be ready to follow up if another interview is requested. Keeping a record gives you a good reason to call and a way to remind the employer of your interest.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Most people get a little bit nervous before a job interview. The best way to prepare is to focus on what you should do and not think about what you should not do.    Before the interview, make sure you know where you will be and figure out how long it will take you to get there. Doing a practice run is a good idea.    During the interview, there are several things you can do to make a good impression:       - Dress professionally    - Arrive on time    - Answer questions honestly    - Be polite to everyone    - Thank the interviewer at the end of the interview       After the interview, some people like to send a thank you note to the interviewer. In the note, you can express your enthusiasm for the job.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Many people get nervous before a job interview. Being well prepared can help you feel comfortable and confident.    Things to do before the interview       - Do some research - Learn everything you can about the company. See what the company's website says. Search for news stories about the company.    - Find out about the position - Find out everything you can about the job. What skills will you need? Who will you report to? How does the company fill the role of the job - is it a path to working up into a management role?    - Know your schedule - Be able to explain your career path and focus.    - Plan your route - If you will have to travel to the interview, plan your travel and time well so you will not be late.    - Review the common interview questions - Find out the kinds of questions interviewers will ask you. It is particularly important to be able to explain any gaps in your employment history, reasons for job changes, and leave of absences.    - Practice the interview - Practice the interview with a career counselor or a friend.    - Bring copies of your resume - Bring several copies of your resume. It is also a good idea to bring a notebook and pen.    - Prepare questions for the interviewer - Think of at least 2 questions to ask the interviewers.    - Prepare your clothes - Wear clothes appropriate for the job. It is better to be overdressed that under dressed.    - Bring a list of references, in case they are asked for       During the interview you will be asked questions about your former jobs, your skills, your educational experiences and your interests. The interviewer will be looking to see how your knowledge, skills, and past experiences match the employer's expectations. You will be evaluated on your qualifications as well as how well you interact with others.    After the interview, you should send a thank-you note. You can do this by mail, e-mail, fax or telephone.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Preparing for an interview involves more than just deciding what to wear :-) Find great tips about different types of interviews:       - Telephone    - Face to face    - Group or panel    - Lunch or dinner       You'll also learn about the types of questions you might hear. prompt: How do I train for a marathon Any tips?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You've made the leap from wishing to running and signed up for that marathon. Good for you! Proper preparation is the key to running a safe and successful marathon. These tips can help you train for your marathon:       - Give your body time to adjust. Give your body time to adapt to new exercises such as running and new diets by introducing them one by one.    - Train with a marathon in mind. A long training run will prepare your legs and mind for the marathon.    - Don't over-train. If you know that down the road you're going to be running long distances, laying down a solid training foundation can slow the rate of injury in your training.    - Take the time for recovery runs. In between your long training runs, recovery runs will bring your legs back to life. They boost your fitness and help you avoid injury.    - Taper. Your taper allows your body to recover and build up energy and strength for the big day. Once you've trained well, enjoy your taper!    - Switch up your snacks. Try different foods and drinks on your training runs to find out which ones agree with you.    - Do a practice run. Practice the marathon route.    - Stick with your training schedule. Practicing your ideal race day pace during training can help you with your pacing on race day.    - Use sunscreen. A sunburn can leave you in pain and make your recovery period longer. Protect your skin with a broad spectrum, water resistant (sweatproof) sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher.    - Stick to tested running shoes. Wear tested running shoes on race day. Don't try out new ones that you haven't broken in.     - Check your neighborhood. Know the busy traffic areas of your neighborhood and avoid them.    - Practice safety. Carry identification and a cell phone, tell others your schedule and route, and wear a reflective vest or clothing for low light conditions.       NIH: National Institute on Aging","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you're training for a marathon, eventually you'll have to run 26.2 miles. But until then, there are some things you can do to prepare for yourself for that big run.    Focus on the essentials    Make sure you have good shoes and clothing. Shoes should be sturdy, with good support and proper cushioning, and should fit comfortably. The shoes you use for training should be the same kind you wear on race day. Test out any clothing or other gear in training to make sure they work for you.    It's important to get enough sleep and rest, pay attention to your nutrition, and stay healthy. Avoid alcohol. If you like coffee or caffeinated soft drinks, it's ok to have the same amount you usually do.    Work with your doctor    If you're going to start training for a marathon, it's a good idea to get a complete physical first, especially if you are 40 or over. If you have heart disease risk factors or other medical conditions, you may need to make adjustments to your training goals.    Increase your distances gradually    Don't try to train for a marathon by doing an extremely long run one day and then recovering for several days. Overdo it slowly. Increase your weekly long run and your weekly mileage by no more than 10 percent each week. Include rest days.    Consider cross-training    Some marathon training workouts can be done with other aerobic activities such as swimming, biking, or walking.    Your run/walk ratio    Most marathoners keep running day after day. However, one of the most important things to remember is that you can mix running and walking segments throughout the marathon. The marathoner Deena Kastor used walking breaks throughout the 2004 Olympics women's marathon to set a new American women's record.    For someone training for their first marathon, walking breaks might be a good idea because it's quicker to train a walk-run pace to the marathon distance than it is to train to run a marathon pace. If you are planning to use walking breaks, an easy way to pace yourself is to start walking when you're short of breath, and start running when you feel recovered.     Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Training for a marathon usually takes 4 to 6 months, depending on how active you are to begin with and your running experience. The essence of good training is gradual progression. When the body can no longer address each increase in training load, it usually means that a plateau has been reached and the body must adapt. You do not want to progress too quickly. Check with your health care professional before beginning any regimen.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How do I write a novel Any tips?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Writing a novel is a significant challenge, requiring a imagination, determination, and a ton of work. Good luck, and never give up! Here are some tips to get you started on your novel: Choose a story idea. Almost any story idea can make a good novel, but it's important that you choose one that will keep your interest for months or years down the line, since that's how long it may take you to write the novel. If you want to write what you know, a novel setting that you know well can help you keep your story straight and can provide a moral or political atmosphere for the story. In contrast, if you want to write what you'd like to know, your novel may help you in making plans for your future. Either way, the next step is to decide the genre of your novel and to decide who your audience will be. Plan the story to help you organize the story before you start to write. General brainstorming can start with a story summit, where you write everything you know, think, or feel about the story idea. From this, you can create a concept map, and choose which story you want to work on. Next, list the key scenes and create an ordinality story matrix. Then, write scene skeletons and white space the outline into a draft. Choose a point of view. Narratives can be told in a variety of points of view. Choose the one that is best for your story. Make sure to stick to the point of view you have chosen. Begin writing the story. Revised and edit the draft if you can. Check your work for \"small issues\" (e.g., spelling and grammar), plot issues (e.g., plot holes and inconsistencies), and stylistic issues (e.g., awkward sentences and clichés). Formal revision means rewriting to improve style and clarity; making major changes in content and organization; moving and rewriting entire paragraphs, sections, chapters, or other long parts; and making the writing more coherent and understandable. Write a query letter. If you want to find an agent or a publisher, you will have to write a query letter to ask whether they which they are interested.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Writing a novel can seem like a huge project. You can always rewrite.    - Create characters that are interesting and that your readers want to spend time with.    - Know what the main conflict is in your story and how you plan to resolve it.    - Read a lot.    - Treat it like a job. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How do you write a novel? Writing a novel is one of the most challenging of all forms. It requires more storytelling skill than a short story. It requires more discipline and time management than a magazine or newspaper article. Novel writing requires planning, research, long periods of solitary work -- and hard work.    That said, I'm going to share what I feel are the top ten tips for writing a novel. They come from my own experience and they probably won't surprise you:       - Start writing as soon as you have a story idea. Don't plan too much beforehand; just write something - anything! - every day. Setting up a blog is a great way to make sure you write something every day.    - Have confidence in your abilities.    - Visualize the story as you write.    - If you ever get stuck, draw on your personal experiences.    - Cut anything that is boring or unnecessary.    - Don't be afraid of writing horrible sentences or paragraphs.    - Finish what you start, whether you feel inspired or not.    - If you are feeling writer's block, writing prompts can help.    - Before writing your novel, watch for interesting ideas and research that you can draw upon. Keep a file.    - When dealing with problems in writing, searching online is probably the best way to find answers.       Writing a novel certainly requires a big commitment of your time and energy, but a lot of that effort is just dealing with problems as they occur. Hopefully by anticipating those problems and having some tools ready, you can handle them with less stress and frustration.    It may seem hard to believe, but having much more writing experience is not on the list! If you write every day and keep the tips above in mind, I promise you will become a much better writer, regardless of your current abilities.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Novels are serious undertakings. They involve many, many hours of work (something like 1,000 or 1,500 hours). Writing a novel is not for everybody, and it should not be taken lightly. Of course, novels have been written by many young people, students, and some people not at all serious about writing, but it wouldn't be wise to do otherwise without a commitment and a plan.    The level of work can be overwhelming. And then there is the emotional side of it: writing a novel requires desire and dedication. You need to be ready to deal with issues concerning belief in yourself, procrastination, fear, resistance, habits, forgiveness - you name it. Some people get discouraged after working so hard on a novel and learning that they are not going to be rich and famous. Others get angry when they can't find a publisher and quit before they finish the book. Even though there is much you can do to avoid these problems (see How to be a writer), it is still wise to be prepared.    Novels are written from the start to the finish. Unlike short stories, where the impact is at the end and the story can therefore be as short as needed, novels require careful pacing and must build gradually to a climax and resolution. There is no single \"process\" through which all novelists pass, some begin by writing the climax or the resolution of their stories first, but whatever the technique, the end product must be well paced and complete.    Novels are composed of characters, which usually involve conflict. \"Conflict\" does not necessarily mean fighting, it means that your story is made with events that clash, so that there is an issue that the characters have to face and resolve, or at least deal with. The two characters who have to deal with each other should be sufficiently different from each other to make it interesting.    Novels have a plot, a storyline and one or more main themes.    Novels employ language, but unlike poetry, which focuses on the language itself, the language in novels mainly serves the purpose of describing story details and expressing what characters do and say.    Novels can belong to a genre, which has guidelines, conventions and expectations. Romance, westerns, fantasy, science fiction and mystery novels are classified as specific genres. Literary fiction is not a genre.    Novels can have subplots or other devices to improve the story, but they are not required.    Novels have a beginning and an end, even if it is an ambiguous ending.    Novels cannot be written in a few hours.    Novel writing is not a linear process. completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How do I write a novel? Have you ever wondered how to write a novel? Have you ever thought of using your knowledge and experiences to write a novel? Have you ever started writing a novel and stopped because you felt stuck and didn't know where to go from there? Well, this article is for you! This article will try to answer the questions of how to write a novel. But don't expect a recipe for writing a novel - there isn't any. When writing a novel, you'll have to work hard, make revisions and revisions, and finally get it published by a commercial publisher. When I began writing my first novel, I committed myself to working on it an hour a day, except for Saturdays, when I worked on it two hours. So I wrote for sixty minutes every day, Monday through Friday, and two hours every Saturday morning. After committing myself to one hour per day, five days a week I began getting letters from people about how to write a novel. So I replied with some information I hope will help you as well. Are there any secrets when it comes to writing a novel? The only secrets there are to writing a novel are focus and follow through. You must be focused in your attention on the actions involved in writing a novel, particularly when the action is on the computer! (For me, writing a novel means keyboard time!) And you must follow through on that focus, even when you don't feel like it - write anyway. There is no other way to become a novelist. Good novelists begin where you are now and incrementally improve their writing skills and knowledge. When I began writing novels, I was terrible! Now, my writing is not as bad. If you finish your first draft and leave it at that, you have not finished your novel. What you must learn about writing novels is how to finish your novels - not necessarily how to write new novels. Have you ever started writing a novel and stopped because you felt stuck and didn't know where to go from there? If so, come back on Saturday and look for my article Finding a Writing Buddy - Novel Writing Support. When writing a novel, the support of other novelists is invaluable. For now, I hope you will write something - a poem, a short story, a personal essay, or a novel - for the fun of it and to get into practice. After all, writers write! {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Like all other forms of writing, fiction writing follows some basic conventions. Help the reader imagine the story by including language that appeals to the senses of sight, taste, smell, hearing, and touch.    - Show, don't tell. Use description rather than telling the reader what is going on.     - Leave your characters with problems. When everything is perfect for your character, nothing has happened. If your character is feeling happy, tell the reader what might happen to make him or her feel differently.     - Show growth. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How to Write Your First Novel in 10 Steps    Have you ever sat in front of a blank screen and wondered how to write a novel? You are not alone. Writing a novel can seem overwhelming to the new novelist. But everyone starts somewhere. Getting your novel written -- and finished -- is the first step to publication. Follow these steps, and you are on your way to writing a novel of your own.       - Decide what the story is about. It's okay to start with a character, or a situation, or a setting. But sooner or later, you'll need to know what your story is about.    - Decide the point of view. Is the narrator a character in the story, like Captain Ahab? Or an outside narrator telling us what the characters do?    - Decide on a setting. Setting isn't just backdrop; it helps tell the story. A day at the beach is very different from a day in prison.    - Decide on your characters. Write a few paragraphs for each of the main characters which describe their appearance, manner of speech, time period, living environment, personality, habits, hopes and dreams, and basic conflict.    - Prepare an outline. You'll find more information on the different types of outlines here.    - Set a writing schedule. Don't mistake inspiration for discipline. During photosynthesis, light energy is absorbed by proteins called reaction centres. These proteins sit in a special membrane: the thylakoid membrane of plants and algae, and the plasma membrane of photosynthetic bacteria. The reaction centres use the absorbed light energy to energize electrons. These electrons pass through an electron transport chain, releasing energy that is used to make ATP and reduced NADP (NADPH). This set of reactions is called the light-dependent reactions.     During the light-independent reactions, the electrons added to NADP+ to make NADPH are added to carbon molecules to build sugars. This process is called \"carbon fixation\" or the Calvin cycle. In plants, these reactions take place in the stroma, the interior space of chloroplasts. To perform carbon fixation, plants use ATP to combine carbon and electrons from NADPH, converting carbon dioxide to sugar. Some of the sugar is consumed for energy. Other sugar goes to build macromolecules used for cellular structure and for storage.     The reduced sugars are one of the main energy storage molecules in living things. Most of the food that people eat comes either directly or indirectly from plants, algae, and photosynthetic bacteria. The overall chemical change during photosynthesis is written as a chemical equation:        6 CO2 + 6 H2O + light energy  C6H12O6 + 6 O2     Chlorophyll is the primary pigment used in photosynthesis. Pigments are compounds that absorb specific wavelengths of light. Leaves are green because chlorophyll absorbs red and blue light. It does not absorb green light, which is reflected, making it the predominant color seen.     Photosynthesis takes place inside plant cells in small things called chloroplasts. Chloroplasts have membranes that contain photosynthetic pigments.     Photosynthesis has two stages:       - Light-dependent reactions capture energy from sunlight. This energy splits water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen, and provides energy to make molecules called ATP and NADPH.      - Light-independent reactions use the ATP and NADPH to glue together carbon dioxide molecules and eventually make glucose.    What, exactly, does the plant do with the glucose it makes? The plant uses it for energy to grow and develop. Most of the glucose molecules a plant makes are used to meet the plant's own energy needs. But a lot of plant energy also goes to make starch, a polysaccharide that serves as a form of energy storage for plants. If you've been eating French fries, you've been eating starch.     Plants are called producers because they produce their own food. And we are called consumers because we consume, or eat, plants and animals to get our energy-storing molecules. When we eat plants, we are taking in some of the energy that the plants stored as starch. We then use the energy from starch for our own cellular respiration. So when you are eating French fries, you are three chemical reactions away from enjoying sunlight. In fact, a few hundred thousand years ago, you were as well.     Plants also store excess glucose as cellulose and sucrose. Cellulose is made and stored in the cell wall and is used for strength and rigidity. Sucrose is transported to other parts of the plant, like stems and roots, where it is converted to be stored as starch. The stored starch will nourish the plant so it can regrow in the spring, or nourish the offspring of the plant.    By producing oxygen and glucose, plants provide energy for both themselves and the animals that consume them. Most producers on Earth are plants.    Source: U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"There are a variety of study techniques out there, some affective, some not so much. The best way to learn something is to practice it - this applies to studying. The more you practice studying the better it gets. Give some new techniques a try to find what works for you. Just remember that the key to retention is repetition. Repetition strengthens the network of neurons that make up each memory and strengthens the links between memories.     Here are three options to consider:       - The SQ3R Method     - Spaced Studying     - Study Quizzes        The SQ3R Method    The SQ3R Method was first introduced in a 1946 book entitled, \"Methods of Study.\" You can think of it as a method that helps you read an article, book, etc by reading it with a purpose. The steps are:              - Survey - Look over the headings, subheadings, and any images/diagrams.     - Questions - Turn the headings or subheadings into questions.     - Read - Read to answer the questions.     - Recite - Put the item down and recite, in your own words, what you learned.     - Review - Review the material you just learned to better commit it to memory.              Spaced Studying    Most students study for exams over several days. But how much time should be spaced in between each session? Spacing your study sessions a little bit apart helps you have better long-term retention of information. But the spacing depends on how much time you have before your exam.     The table below shows recommendations for space intervals according to how long you have before the test.        How much time you have before the exam     How to space your study sessions       1 week    Space your study sessions 1 day apart       2 weeks    Space your study sessions 2 to 3 days apart       1 month or more    Space your study sessions 5 to 7 days apart             Study Quizzes     Study quizzes can be very helpful. Self-testing helps you learn the material as you test yourself. Correct answers provide confidence and incorrect answers reinforce your learning when you review the materials.     Here are some ways you can quiz yourself:             - Write questions, based on the key concepts being studied, then test yourself or have someone else test you.     - Use flashcards. Write a key word, idea, or concept on the front and the definition or information on the back. You can make a quiz with the front of the card being the question and the back being the answer.     - Take available online or textbook quizzes. Some eBooks, like the Federal Benefits: Retirement Handbook, have quizzes. After reading a chapter, you can take the quiz and get immediate feedback on your answers.                 Kentuckians can get involved with the Kentucky Virtual Library's Real Kids...Real Stories Contest that has a quizmaking workshop. You can click on the link and \"take the workshop\" online to learn how to make your own quiz. prompt: What are some effective study techniques How do I begin?
completions:
{"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How you study can be as important as what you study. Different techniques work better for different subjects and different people. Here we suggest a few of the most effective. You may need to try out a few to see which you like best.    One method that can keep you focused and help you avoid burnout is the "25 to 5" study rule. For every 25 minutes that you spend studying, take a break for 5 minutes. Be sure to take your eyes off your books and walk away for those 5 minutes! After three - four cycles, take a longer break.    A few suggestions to keep in mind: Make a schedule - Set aside a regular time for studying. Make a plan for each study session. Decide which topics you will review and what materials you need.    Tackle your least favorite subjects first - Once you get through the things you like the least, you'll feel great.    Begin early - Don't wait until the night before the exam. Effective studying takes time.    Deputize - Study with a friend. It can make studying more fun.    Eat before a study session - Your brain and body need energy. Like any muscle, your brain works better with a steady supply of glucose. Stay hydrated too - Your brain also needs a steady supply of oxygen.    Find a good place to study - A place with good lighting, a comfortable table and chair, few distractions, and all of your materials.    Think positively - Believe in yourself!
                    

Confusing English Words / Homophones","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are some effective study techniques Please help.
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"There are two main categories of techniques: how to start studying and how to keep studying.    Getting started       - What is the best way to review: aloud or silently? - The best way to review is aloud. When a new word or concept is learned, say it aloud and say what it means, then try to use it in a sentence. For example, \"Cecilia is mellifluous; she has a sweet voice.\" You are using hearing and sight, and saying the word yourself helps unify all movements in the central nervous system.       - How do I prepare for a test? - To prepare for a test, make sure you understand the assigned reading, and answer as many of the questions at the end of chapters or units as you can. Answer the practice questions provided by your teacher, and make your own flashcards and tests. Group study also may help.    - How do I get myself to really study? - The keys to motivation are closing the door so you won't be interrupted, setting a timer, and having all your supplies ready.    Keeping with it       - How long should my study sessions be? - One of the most important parts of the brain for learning is your long term memory. That part works best when you have breaks. So, if you are going to study for hours, make sure you take a 5-10 minute break every 40-50 minutes.    - Is there a best place to study? - Some people do well in new places every time you study, but most people do best by having a single, consistent place to study.    - How do I keep from getting bored? - You can study with friends or by yourself, but it's best not to mix...\n    Centers for Disease Control and Prevention","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are some effective study techniques What should I know?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Different study techniques may work better for different subjects and for different people. You may need to experiment to find what works best for you. To get started, here are some things you can try. They may help you make the most of your study time.    - Have a plan and start early     - Decide how much time you want to spend studying. Decide what you need to accomplish during that time. Then get started.     - Shorter is better. Six separate 50-minute sessions are far better than an all-night cram.    - Organize your study zone     - Choose a place that has good lighting and space for spreading out your materials.    - Choose a place that is free of distractions and stored temptations. That may mean studying somewhere other than your dorm room of apartment.    - Make sure you have everything you need before you start - pens, paper, textbooks, computer, etc. Getting up to search for something will make it harder for you to refocus.    - Minimize distractions     - If you cannot study at home alone, choose a coffee shop or a library and commit to spending set amounts of time there.    - Turn off the television. It is hard to study when you are trying to listen to commercials.    - If music helps you concentrate, have some \"study music\" to put on.     - Take breaks     - Frequent short breaks during study sessions help your brain absorb information.     - Get up and walk around between study sessions.    - Drink plenty of water and eat healthy snacks.    - Pay attention to class     - The hardest part of learning something is getting it into your brain the first time.     - Take careful notes in class. It is easier to concentrate on the lecture if you do.    - Some people find it helpful to tape lectures so they can listen again. Check with your teacher first.    - Listen carefully and ask questions - don't just wait your turn to speak.     - Use your time outside of class     - It is easier to study material you are already somewhat familiar with than to learn it for the first time.     - Before class, review your notes from previous lectures and read the material for the upcoming class.    - After class, review the notes you took in class that day and fill in any blanks. Then test yourself on the key points - review the previous lecture before starting the next one.    - When reading make sure you understand what you are reading. Look up unfamiliar words or concepts. Highlight or underline key ideas and terms.    - Keep track of deadlines so you are sure to have enough time to study. The more time you have, the better.    - Use memory aids     - Arrange things into logical sequences     - Learning to use a table of contents to navigate your textbook allows you to search a smaller list, such as a chapter, to find what you are looking for. Organizing material into an outline is another way to learn a logical sequence.     - Use flash cards     - Flash cards help you to learn and review new terms and concepts. Place the term you are learning on one side of an index card and the definition or explanation on the back. Have a friend or family member quiz you, or quiz yourself.     - Use mnemonic devices: they make the material more meaningful and make it easier to remember     - Examples include rhymes, songs, or acronyms (such as using HOMES to remember the names of the Great Lakes: Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, Superior).    - Use pictures, charts and graphs     - Draw pictures, charts and graphs to help facts and ideas stick in your mind.    - Try to relate what you are studying to your own life and experiences    - Write the information    - Writing notes over again either by hand or on the computer helps your brain retain the information.     - Repeat things to yourself     - Repeat facts or concepts that you need to memorize out loud.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

What works for one person might not work for another. However, many people find the following study techniques to be effective.       - Ask questions    - Use cues    - Use active recall    - Use spaced repetition    - Use interleaving       Cognitive scientists found that, for most people, these methods dramatically increase learning - by not just a little, but a lot.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The key to powerful learning is to engage in \"active learning.\" Active learning involves mental effort beyond just reading your notes or highlighting text. It is much more effective to test yourself again and again than to simply review material over and over. Spacing out your study sessions--instead of cramming--helps too. Some of the most effective active study techniques include:       - Self-testing: Test yourself on the material using flash cards, answering chapter questions, doing practice problems, or trying to recall information without a book or notes.    - Elaborating: Explain and describe ideas with many details.    - Interleaving: Practice jumping back and forth between different types of problems or different subjects.    - Visualization: Take what you are trying to learn and turn it into a mental picture. Sketching or drawing a diagram can help too.    - Generation: Answer a question or solve a problem before being shown the answer or the solution.       Growing evidence also suggests that physical activity boosts learning. Getting exercise before studying and during breaks can improve your attention and memory.     Department of Education","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Active recall and spaced repetition are among the most effective study techniques. Active recall - Practice bringing information to mind. This strengthens the neural pathways that lead to that information, making it easier to retrieve later. Combined with elaboration - by asking 'why' you make the associations - active recall leads to exceptional retention. Spaced repetition - Review material over a series of increasingly longer breaks in between. To optimize the retrieval practice, you want to wait long enough to almost forget the material, then bring it back to mind. This is the principle behind spaced repetition software like Anki and Memrise. Others include the Leitner system and the Ebbinghaus schedule. Other techniques to consider: Cornell note taking, Interleaved practice, Mind maps.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Here are some effective study techniques: Deep processing and elaborative rehearsal - Deep processing involves elaborative rehearsal where you link the information you are trying to learn to previous knowledge. Distributing study - Distributing study is a learning strategy, that incorporates spreading out study activities so they are not crammed into a single session. Distributing study results in better long-term retention of the material. Practice testing - Practice tests usually involve trying to recall information without having it in front of you. Practice tests can be flashcards, fill-in-the-blank tests or full practice tests that mimic the one you will be taking. (You don't have to grade it). Interleaved practice - Interleaved practice is a learning strategy, where you mix, or interleave, multiple subjects or topics while you study. There is evidence that interleaving improves long-term retention of material. Self-explanation - Self-explanation involves creating explanations for what you are learning. You can do this by either speaking out-loud or writing. Teaching others - The protege effect, states that teaching others leads to better learning. When teaching others, you learn better yourself. Teaching others involves preparing yourself to teach, learning the material and following through with the teaching. (http://www.helpguide.org/articles/education/learning-study-skills.htm)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"\"Cogito, ergo sum.\" - Rene Descartes, Discourse on Method, 1637    René Descartes is often credited as the first modern philosopher. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Here are some famous philosophical quotes with brief explanations.  1. \"The unexamined life is not worth living.\" - Socrates. Socrates was tried and convicted for treason, and condemned to death by poison. This was a surprise to him, because he did not believe he had done anything wrong. He believed that doing wrong harmed the soul, so why would anyone wish to harm the soul by doing wrong? Hence, he was not afraid to die; he thought it was a greater evil to commit injustice than to suffer injustice. Socrates wanted to escape, but he did not want to give up the chance to convince the jury that they were committing injustice. At the same time, if he wanted to become immortal in fame, he must first die; so he let his enemies condemn him. On the way to his death, he took the opportunity to point out to Crito: \"the unexamined life is not worth living.\" 2. \"God is dead.\" - Nietzsche. Nietzsche was famous for his criticism of religion and morality. Famous for \"God is dead\" (from The Gay Science), Nietzsche's statement was that the Enlightenment had 'killed' the possibility of belief in a coherent, traditional God. He saw that only good would remain if there was a Holy God, and only evil if there was not.  3. \"A man is what he makes of himself.\" - Jean-Paul Sartre. This statement can be understood both literally and metaphorically. Sartre, a leading existentialist, indicated that humans have freedom and choice. What this means is that you and I are not forced to do anything; if there is any type of thing that we can choose to not do, it follows that we can also choose to do it. The freedom that humans have is tantamount to the freedom of God, and humans have no excuse for their behavior. Choosing something is to take responsibility for that thing, and so in particular humans take responsibility for the whole of their lives. So if you are what you make of yourself, you are not made by: genetics, your parents, your life, or society. You are always free to choose to be something else. This is why Sartre said that \"man is condemned to be free.\" A metaphorical understanding of this statement is that life has no predetermined meaning and a person who lives this way is not being true to existentialism. Dictionary.com, Merriam-Webster and Wikiquote provide many other famous philosophical quotes with explanations.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"From taking a walk to drinking water, these daily habits can improve your health. Getting enough sleep Getting enough sleep is important. Most adults need 7 or more hours of good-quality sleep each night. Children and teens need even more sleep than adults, and may also benefit from having a set bedtime. Lack of sleep has been linked to many health problems, including obesity and type 2 diabetes. Plus, not getting enough sleep can affect hormone levels that control hunger. You may end up wanting to eat more than usual and gain excess weight. Sleep deprivation may also cause a lack of energy, affecting your motivation to be active. At the other end of the spectrum, getting too much sleep (more than 9 or10 hours regularly) can also make you feel sluggish.     Choose healthy meals and snacks    The foods you choose are a main source of vitamins and minerals for your body. Make each bite count. That means choosing whole, healthy foods (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, and low-fat dairy). Skip highly processed foods, which are higher in calories and often have added sugar, saturated and trans fats, and sodium. When you eat them, watch your portion sizes. Also, pay attention to your hunger. Ask yourself \"Am I really hungry? What do I want to eat? How hungry am I?\"    Drinking enough water    Our bodies are 60 percent water. Water is in every cell, tissue and organ in your body. Without it, you can't survive. You lose water every day through your skin, breathing and urine. You need to replace it by drinking fluids and eating foods that contain water. How much water you need depends on many factors, including your body size, activity level, the weather where you live and your health. A common idea is to drink eight 8-ounce glasses of water a day. But that might not be right for everyone. A good rule of thumb is to drink water when you are thirsty and drink enough to satisfy your thirst.     Every movement counts!    A habit everyone should strive for is to move your body every day, such as taking a thirty-minute walk. More important is to limit the amount of time you spend sitting. A combination of aerobic and strength training exercise is best. Here are some specific benefits - it       - Controls your weight    - Combats health conditions and diseases    - Improves your mood    - Boosts your energy    - Helps your brain    - Promotes better sleep       Centers for Disease Control and Prevention","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Learning a new language is easier said than done. However, if you follow a few sensible guidelines from the start, you can avoid common mistakes and learn more efficiently.     First, you should choose a language for the right reasons. Avoid popular languages just because they're popular. Also, avoid \"trendy\" languages simply because all your friends are learning them. Choose a language because it makes sense for you. It may enhance your career. Maybe you have friends or family who speak another language. Or you just enjoy learning about different cultures.    Next, you should set a clear, attainable goal to work toward. This will help you stay focused and motivated, and make it easier to monitor your progress. Do you want to be completely bilingual, or just pick up a few phrases for a trip? A clear goal will help you decide how much time and effort to put into learning.    Learning a language also involves a lot of memorization. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What mechanisms drive global climate? However, the relative importance of these mechanisms (and the relative strength of their influence on climate) also depends on one's location and altitude. Atmospheric composition - Atmospheric composition includes the amount of gases, liquids, and solids in the air that surrounds the Earth at any given time. Atmospheric composition can change quickly or slowly, depending on the factor influencing it. For example, the amount of water vapor in the air changes frequently, whereas the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) changes over longer periods of time.  Atmospheric composition can also be influenced by human activity, such as fossil fuel burning or land clearing, which releases CO2 and other gases, solids, and liquids into the air. Depending on the type of matter that is present in the atmosphere, that matter either retains or repels heat. For example, greenhouse gases (GHGs) like CO2 absorb and re-emit infrared radiation, trapping heat in the atmosphere. Other gases, like sulfate aerosols, reflect shortwave radiation from the sun, cooling the planet. The overall effect is that a portion of solar energy that reaches Earth is absorbed and some is reflected back into space. Together, the influences that warm or cool the climate system are referred to as climate forcings. Forcing can be either positive (tending to warm the surface) or negative (tending to cool the surface). The net forcing is a key factor in how much warming Earth has and will experience.
