{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Burnout can diminish your energy, focus, and sense of well-being. The key is to act early.    \"Burnout leaves us listless and exhausted and makes us stray from our life goals and lose motivation,\" says psychologist Christina Maslach, Ph.D., of the University of California at Berkeley. \"It also limits our feelings for other people and lowers productivity. By the time we experience burnout, our energy and motivation are already very low.\"    Stress is a normal part of life. If we have to deal with a problem, it makes sense that we would feel stressed. Burnout is different from everyday stress, though. It is a state of emotional, physical, and mental exhaustion caused by excessive and prolonged stress. It usually happens when you feel overwhelmed and unable to keep up. Burnout can lessen your ability to feel sympathy for others and make it difficult to build relationships.    Recognize the signs    Everyone's experience with burnout is different. However, there are certain signs that may indicate that you are suffering from burnout:       - Feeling tired and drained most of the time    - Lowered immunity, frequent illnesses    - Habitual headaches, back pain    - Changes in appetite or sleep habits       Psychological signs of burnout can include a sense of failure and self-doubt; feeling helpless, trapped and defeated; detachment, feeling alone in the world; loss of motivation; increasingly cynical and negative outlook; decreased satisfaction and sense of accomplishment.    Prevent burnout    Sometimes it is hard to act before you feel yourself falling into burnout. It is best, though, to try to prevent it. The following tips can help: If you are feeling exhausted, you need rest. Take breaks throughout the day. Getting up from your desk for a short walk or doing some stretching exercises can mean the difference between coping and burning out. Try to get more sleep. Childcare, commutes, deadlines, late events, and social outings often cut into sleep, which leaves you tired and less able to cope. Perhaps by cutting back on social events, you will be able to catch more ZZZs.    Reassess your priorities. Does your day revolve around putting out fires at work? Do you spend too much time cleaning, with co-workers who stress you out, or with friends you don't really enjoy? Make time for things that are important to you, such as your family or exercise. Review your goals and values, and work on living a life consistent with them.\n Clean up your diet. An excess of caffeine is likely to make you keyed up and jumpy. A diet high in refined sugar and fat can make you feel sluggish. Try to eat healthy balanced meals whenever possible. Find ways to relax and unwind. Yoga, massage, meditation, self-hypnosis, acupuncture, progressive muscle relaxation, or simply a hot bath can help.    Establish boundaries. Don't overextend yourself and learn how to say no. Avoid people who stress you out and limit your exposure to news broadcasts and books that deal with negative topics. Surround yourself with positive and happy people.    If you are feeling unappreciated or taken for granted, make yourself a priority. Treat yourself to something special.       Components of burnout    Burnout has three key components: exhaustion, cynicism, and a feeling of inefficacy and lack of accomplishment. Getting involved in activities can help you lessen these feelings: try to avoid procrastination, switch up your routine, and take on challenges to increase your feelings of accomplishment. Getting support from other people can help, as well. In centralized institutions, records of transactions are stored in one central place. It's like writing down the name of everyone who has given you money or to whom you have given money on a single paper.    Blockchains are a type of \"distributed ledger.\" Every computer on the blockchain network has a copy of this ledger, so there are many copies of it. If you want to add a transaction on the ledger, an algorithm on the network has to approve it. When it does, your new \"page\" is linked to the chain of previous transactions. The process is designed to make it very difficult to tamper with records. prompt: What's the difference between AI and machine learning Any tips?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Is AI the same as machine learning? Machine learning doesn't equal AI, and AI doesn't equal machine learning. Machine learning is one of many ways of doing artificial intelligence. This visualization breaks it down: AI is a broad field of study that makes machines seem like they have human intelligence. That involves a lot of things - from planning, to natural language processing (NLP), to simulating human intelligence levels or behavior, to actual robotic control. Machine learning is a specific subfield of AI dealing with algorithms and statistical models that computer systems use to perform a specific task without using explicit instructions, relying on patterns and inference instead. It is seen as a part of artificial intelligence. For example, neural network algorithms are often categorized as machine learning, while genetic algorithms are often described as artificial intelligence. (Though there is much argument about these almost semantic level differentiations)    Tips for getting a job in AI or ML: Go back to school. The best paid computer scientists go to grad school; PhDs make more money on average than master level folks, who do better than people with just a bachelors. Anything that ports over a heavy math component counts; computer science bachelors degrees have the smallest math component out of any math intensive bachelors degree other than possibly education. The field changes quickly, but if you want a better career start in CS and a better rise in pay as you grow, here is a highly detailed non-comprehensive post on where a computer science degree can get you.    Another piece of advice for anyone switching careers: Get in while it's growing. The numbers are there. I took an intro to AI class almost 20 years ago, and from a recruiting perspective, the greatest growth in AI jobs is in AI/ML software engineer jobs: A software engineer is kind of your standard job - design, develop, test software, implement new features, fix bugs ... they're called programmers but often they don't program for a living, they engineer software. We now have specialized AI software engineers who do that same work in a machine learning context. The field is growing fast, so there's opportunity there for investment in education in this application area.    If you are just looking for information, here is a Wikipedia list of fields in artificial intelligence. (Heads up, it's huge!) Mind Reading - One application of machine learning is to estimate the mental state of a person you're looking at - by reading their brain waves, it can estimate whether they're happy or sad, angry or relaxed.    Image Recognition - An active field in machine learning is image recognition. We're already using optical character recognition to translate pictures of signs into text messages, but soon we won't be bothered by having to look at signs at all.    Predictive Algorithm - One of the things machine learning does best is to find patterns in data sets, without knowing what to look for in advance, so it can be used as a predictive algorithm to find the best path in difficult-to-explore spaces.    Look for the labor pool where you can make the labor market work for you. AI, software engineering, and computer science jobs in general are in very high demand - look at the wage data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics - and the degree of competition you face is roughly the number of people in the laborious process of getting ready to apply divided by the number of jobs out there. Fields like pharmacy, accounting, and nursing are winding down in terms of growth opportunities, and the competition is fierce for any opening. In computer science, just as soon as you are ready, there will be more jobs for you than there are people to fill them. And the number of people who enter the computer science field every year isn't really that large. There's not a lot of turnaround. It pays better than anywhere else to be adding skills.    Once you get started in the field, people who have worked for decades talk about having to continually learn a huge amount in order to keep up with the field. There are lots of free learning resources out there - for example, Wenhao Xu's Bars and Stripes. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"AI and machine learning (ML) are not the same thing. ML is a type of AI that allows software applications to become more accurate in predicting outcomes without being explicitly programmed. For example, if an AI is mimicking human cognition, it may learn the way a human learns, either on-the-job or through experience. You don't necessarily need this kind of learning for an AI to be \"intelligent,\" however - sometimes a simple program that follows a decision tree will suffice. In this case, the AI is not \"learning,\" but already knows exactly how it should respond regardless of its interactions with the user. The key difference is that AI can be programmed, it does not need to learn, and in fact may fail to do so. On the other hand, ML always learns but is not necessarily intelligent. ML is the practice of using data and algorithms to imitate the way that humans learn, gradually improving its accuracy. ML cannot successfully mimic human cognition without data, but it can learn without interaction (though interaction with humans can speed things along considerably). If an AI system uses a learning algorithm, it needs to receive data, analyze it, learn from it, and then use what has been learned to make predictions, calculations, and decisions. For example, if you teach a program to identify pictures of cats, you can give it a whole set of cat images so that it learns features common to cats, such as their pointy ears, whiskers, and unique face shape. When you give the program a new picture, it will use what it learned from the known pictures to identify the features and decide whether a new animal it sees is a cat or not. The more images you give it, the better it will get at the task. prompt: What’s the best way to organize my time What should I know?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Whether you have kids, a full-time job, volunteer activities, or other responsibilities, it's likely that you've felt overwhelmed by everything you have to do. Often, there just doesn't seem to be enough time. Then it feels like you've accomplished very little by the end of the day and you ask yourself: \"Why am I so tired?\" One problem is that it's hard to say \"no.\" You're likely to feel pressure from all directions: your children or spouse, your friends, your co-workers, your manager, your boss. Or you feel guilty when you say \"no.\" The reality is that you will be happier if you knowingly say \"yes\" to some things and \"no\" to others. Time management can help you to do this. Here are some tips:       - Make a list of everything you need to do. Prioritize the list, and focus on the most important things.    - Make a schedule. According to your priorities, decide what you are going to do during the next day, the next week and the next month.    - Limit distractions. Don't allow e-mail or telephone interruptions when you are busy or thinking.    - Focus on one thing at a time.    - Get started. Break large tasks into smaller ones, and just do it.    - Make plans for large, time-consuming projects. Postpone less important things.    - Be flexible with your plan. Unexpected delays occur, be ready to adjust.    - Take breaks, make time for yourself.    - Make a list of things you need to take with you when you leave the house.    - Take some things with you, like reading or knitting, if you are going to be spending time waiting.       NIH Office of Research Services","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The first workable prototype of the Internet came in the late 1960s with the creation of ARPANET, or the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network. On October 29, 1969, the first message was sent over the ARPANET from computer science Professor Leonard Kleinrock's laboratory at UCLA to the second network node at Stanford Research Institute. Later, scientists connected many universities and research facilities to the ARPANET, which later developed into the Internet.    In 1972, Ray Tomlinson introduced network e-mail. Cerf and Bob Kahn are often called the fathers of the Internet.     The 1980s saw expansion of the ARPANET and its adoption for public, commercial use. In 1982, the Internet Protocol Suite (TCP/IP) was standardized, and the ARPANET officially changed to using TCP/IP on January 1, 1983, marking the beginning of the internet. The same year, the Domain Name System (DNS) was established, making it easier for users to access websites. The 1980s also saw the development of key internet protocols such as FTP, SMTP, HTTP and HTML.    In 1989, Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web while working at CERN. The web helped to popularize the internet among the public. The internet reached beyond the research and military communities in the 1990s. By 1997, the internet had one hundred million users worldwide. The World Wide Web also saw a boom of growth in the late 1990s with the rise of ISPs and household computers.
